												I'm a big fan of turn-based squad tactics games - Xcom, Fallout Tactics, Shadowrun, etc. If you are also a fan of these, you'd probably find something worth liking in Halfway. Overall, it was a challenging, well-written game that I really enjoyed despite a few quirks.DifficultyThis is not for the faint of heart. You will probably find yourself re-playing some of the missions several times, trying to find the best mix of tactics and team cominations. Especially in later levels, when some very dangerous enemies show up, You'll probably want to (if you don't feel like it's cheating) make a habit of simply restarting the level once you've got an idea of what enemies and level layout you're dealing with. But the flipside is that FINALLY beating a mission is really rewarding. VariationBoth weapons, armor, and enemies seemed to have the same pattern going on - they're split up into basic "types" and then there's several "levels" within each type. Sniper rifles - Mk1, Mk2, Mk3, etc.. Armor with high shield recharge but low damage resistance...Mk1, Mk2, Mk3, etc.. Enemy with no shield but huge amount of health...easy version, medium version, toughest version. It makes for very clear-cut tactics - you're making definite decisions about what kind of weapon/armor to equip, and then you just keep upgrading it. You see certain enemies, you use specific tactics and abilities. While I do, on a base level, really appreciate that the mechanics of how these all work and fit together has been worked out and clearly signposted for me, I did feel at times that the lack of diversity and "grey area" sometimes made the game feel a bit empty.StoryI loved the story, hands down. I liked the characters, I enjoyed seeing their interactions, and I was interested in seeing how things would play out and how the story would resolve up through the end. There are NO dialogue trees. You are essentially watching pre-determined dialogue at every "conversation" in the game, but I still enjoyed it, even in places where it was a bit cheesy.Tactical playstyleThis game takes a page from Xcom and Shadowrun in that there's essentially two "actions" per turn per character. No points or anything like that to manage. You can move and shoot, reload and shoot, move and use an item or ability, take an aimed shot, etc. Very straightforward, very accessible. My one gripe (which I've seen others echo) is that the "retaliation" ability kinda sucks - it's basically "overwatch," but you're essentially holding onto one or both action points to fire at any enemy THAT FIRES AT YOU. Not enemies that become visible, not enemies that walk right up next to you, not enemies that fire on teammates - only the ones that shoot at the specific character who has activated "Retaliation." Be aware - using it properly can actually save a run, but not using it or overrelying on it can be devastating.No Leveling UpThat's right. No leveling up your guys. You can give them "stims" which will permanently raise one or more stats, but those arerisky to use more than 5 of per character. You also should definitely be upgrading your weapons and armor as you find new stuff to use. But you absolutely, especially in late-game, need to play cautiously. If a tough enemy gets a concentrated burst of fire on you, or if a squadmate gets flanked and fired on by several enemies at once, you could go from "sitting in cover with full shields and health" to "only 2 of 4 squaddies still alive" VERY fast.Buy this game if:-You like squad-based tactics games-You don't want to have to do too much micromanaging in your Squad-tactics game-You want a game with a sci-fi horror kind of feel to it-You want a game that's challenging but rewardingDon't buy this game if:-You want a game that'll be easy to play through-You want to micromanage every aspect of your characters' stats or have lots of control over how they develop-You want to charge into every scenario with guns blazing, ignoring cover-You want a game with a rich, complicated, branching storyline

												Popular tags suggest Halfway is RPG and TBS. I say it is else. The main activities of Halfway are TBS fighting, running between fights and observing the linear story progression.  No options in dialogs, no choice, no consequences, like reading a book. So only fighting includes actual gameplay. To win a fight you have 2-8 units and ability to give them simple orders. In theory that is enough. But there is a problem. You see, you can't actually develop your units. Every unit has 2 predefined abilities and 4 predefined stats. Stats can be slooooowly changed with equipment. A certain piece of equipment can be found in a certain crate/locker on a certain level. No random generation. And there is no vast variety of loot, you will take from mission at best 3 new pieces which are slightly better than your current. Also on most missions you have to take fully or partially predefined team for the plot's sake. So unless you have the full game guide you can't predict and plan your unit development.But who needs fancy pseudo RPG babysitting when you have tactics! Not here. Here you usually open a door and conveniently placed enemy spots your guy. Enemies as equipment are placed in certain places on certain maps, no random at all. And there is no way to predict what is waiting ahead, only try and error. Also often you get local special treatment: your guys enter certain small area, trigger cutscene, take bad positions without your control, bla-bla-bla, then enemies appear from thin air, take a turn, take good positions and only then you are given a chance to react.So here you are on a pretty tight prebuilt level with predefined units wearing predefined gear standing in disadvantaged predefined positions against preplased predefined set of enemies which corner you if you run and get to point blank range if you don't within two turns at best. Under this circumstance no tactic is involved. Basicly you must perform only one specific for every battle set of actions.Thereby Halfway genre is not RPG or TBS but point and click adventure. Don't buy Halfway if you love TBS or RPG, buy if you like quests.

												Hard to believe this game was put together by so few people.  Hands down, it is an absolute marvel and joy to play, and I'm really hoping for a sequel.The plot is the standard sci-fi fare, you awake from cryo-sleep on a long-haul space flight, finding that your ship is randomly hyperjumping through space, whilst all around you humanoid mutants lunge at you from the shadows.  It is down to you to find fellow survivors, salvage for spare guns and ammo, figure out whats going on and attempt to escape the nightmare.  But the way it is told deserves particular praise, with all exposition delivered piece-by-piece through character conversations and in-game encounters.  The dialogue stays fairly safe throughout but there's at least a couple of characters of note.The gameplay, though straightforward, offers some serious amount of depth.  It's a turn-based top-down squad focused strategy game.  You spend the majority of your time being ambushed by mutants, lunging for cover, returning fire, and trying not to be overrun.  Once the smoke clears you salvage the area for weapons, ammo and medikits for future use or for conversion to credits to buy other much needed gear.  But you can't just point your guys at the enemy and expect to win.  Get ready to make strategic choices about defensive positions, weapon loadouts, which characters to bring, when to fall back and when to bring the fight to the enemy.  There are also some light RPG elements which is very nicely and uniquely implemented.  You don't gain experience per se, but rather you trawl the crates and lockers of the war-torn environments to salvage various stimpacks, each of which offer your characters an improvement to their agility, health or aiming ability.  But you can't just pump your favourite guys up to ridiculous levels, as each character can only handle 5 stimpacks before some side-effects become known, so you have to think twice about which characters get what stimpacks.The difficulty is very well balanced.  Usual walkover for first few levels, before a slow and steady rise over the considerably long campaign to some very challenges end levels.  There are indeed plentiful levels, with a varied environment and layout, each of which you must complete in one go, but they are short enough that the few times you do die won't induce much frustration.  Between each level you get to return to your makeshift camp to reload and refit and change your squad lineup.The aesthetics are wonderful.  Though oddly bright and colorful for a game about a grim slog through unforgiving, mutant-infested spaceship corridors, its the little details that make this game come to life.  From the gore-stained corridors, to the way your fallen foes disintegrate into ash, to the spent shell casings ejected from your varied weaponry, this game is one that draws you in and bathes you in its beautiful gloominess.I've only the one criticism, and maybe this was just me, but I couldn't find a way to change the text font size, so those of short sight may be in for a spot of bother.So in summary, this is a game you absolutely must own, and it's available at a very reasonable price!

												Simple and good turn-based strategy game.  On board the Goliath, you gather the remaining crew members and figure out what is happening on the ship.  Once you gather enough members of the ships crew, you pick out which ones to take with you on a mission, each offering unique skills.  It is important to stock up on supplies, which can be purchased at a kiosk.  To earn credits, you will need to "recycle" items you collect from missions.  Basically, you turn in armor, weapons, or items for credits.Although unique in the beginning, the enemies begin to run dry on the unique skills.  Most either charge at you to attack melee or will keep at a distance to fire at you.  This was one problem I had with the game, it stays like this until toward the end.  However, I do feel that this gave the game a bit more realism, as the creatures you fight were human members on board the ship, not four arm, five legged beasts.Enemies also have a bad habit of appearing in random places when the ship goes through a jump.  Only in a few instances can this be a problem because you may have set your crew to physically attack one enemy, kill it, and suddenly have four more appear right where your crew are, placing them in a tight spot because it would be ideal if they were further away and behind cover.Some other small issues I had was the occasional 82% chance to successfully hit only to miss, twice in a row.  This is rare and not something that breaks the game.  The other issue is the text is difficult to read when selecting missions on the right side of the ship map.  Again, not game breaking, just slightly annoying.Overall, I would recommend this game.  It is simple that you can play a mission or two if you have 30 minutes to an hour to spare.  Not many lengthy game conversations.  Each character provides a unique skill to be of use in combat.  And the story is interesting.
